>>18929363
So the secret to getting good steak is searing it. I know youve heard people talk about it, its pretty much the best and only way to do it.

Your oven has a setting called "broil" which turns the top coils on as hot as it can go and quickly burns anything you stick in there.

What you do is stick the steak on a pan, season it with whatever seasoning you want.
Put the oven rack near the top.
Turn it on broil and wait till the top gets a hard crispy "sear" crust on it, youll hear it sizzle
Itll take like 7-8 minutes
Flip it and do the other side for 7 or 8 minutes
Itll be cooked perfect.

posts.com:
>>18929363
Pan fry. The times assume a 1.5" thick ribeye cooked to about medium; adjust based on your steak type/toughness, size & doneness preference:
- bring steak to room temp, let sit out about an hour; less for thinner steaks
- pat dry with paper towels
- sprinkle salt & pepper, rub it in on both sides
- heat stainless pan to med-high (I don't use iron or teflon, so don't know how they'll differ in cook times/methods)
- put ~1-2 tblspoon hi-temp oil in pan: lard, tallow, ghee or veg. oil of preference
- put steak in, let sit
- after 7 minutes, flip
- baste with butter
- after 5 minutes, steak out

Optional sauce from fond (the burnt crud in bottom of pan):
- diced shallot (or onion), garlic in same pan
- soften them up a bit
- pour in about half a glass of red wine (could use beef broth, but acidity from wine is said to help; I don't know why)
- use spatula to lift up the stickings from the bottom of the pan, mix with rest
- let it sizzle for a bit as the wine reduces to almost half
- add pat of butter to give it creamier consistency
- pour over steak

Some good steak recipes, entertaining to watch, at least:

Jacques Pepin TV show from the 90s:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FCCfeGPKl6s

This is more of a commercial for Knorr seasoning, but still a fine recipe:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BfSl3WwqYls

>Highest difficulty to make

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Its most easiest to manufacture, you just need dough tubes that exit through a mold with small holes, its the easiest to transport due to small area raw spaghetti takes, its easy to eat compared to most other shapes.
Sauces grip it well thanks to large surface area, its satisfying to get a mouthful of sauced up spaghetti into a fork and eat it, the mouthfeel is great. Other shapes are harder to wrap on a fork due to increased friction if its flat pasta or they're not long pasta in which case you're just sticking fork down to grab individual pieces which is less fun.

Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

You are buying a good that is being sold to you as a goodgoy lifestyle product, like a bottle of Armani cologne. There is nothing uniquely Scottish to a bottle of scotch whisky in 2023. It is a globohomo product that is purposefully aimed toward the same soijaks who buy Bespoke Post and Beard Oil and wax philosophic dilletantism about the "delicious" and "complex" smokey peat flavor of Islay malts while looking down their noses at Speyside drinkers, pretending that Don Draper is "literally me" not knowing they're all part of the same retarded, consoomerist goycattle, drinking the epitome of a fake product.

Scotch drinkers are the worst.

t. Scotch drinker

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18929325
I make things that are freezer worthy to be saved for later and use them as my work lunches. I make six each so that I have a growing stock of multiple meals on standby. If I'm not up for whatever I made for this week, I can grab one from the previous week or just say fuck it and make something else without my previous meals going to waste.
I do it because I'm both too lazy to cook some days and don't want to fall to the temptations of fast food too often.
In the freezer things can be kept safely for months, although certain foods are not freezer worthy and lose quality once frozen. In the fridge most things loose quality much quicker and can go bad. Soups, chilis, pasta, and certain leftovers are fridge worthy and get better with time, but stuff like chicken, fried foods, and veggies gets gross quickly.
It's a lifehack for lazy people, dieting people, and maybe poorfags who cook in bulk, but mostly a meme for anyone else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sipping on some of "That Camphor Cake" from LP
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1188363800/that-camphor-cake-400g
It is a aged white label production sheng cake made sometime in the late 1990's to very early 2000's. Very gnarly looking, lots of stems and large misshapen leaves but the tea is undoubtedly well aged. The cake is aptly titled, camphor is its dominant flavor. Reminds me of moth balls and aromatic cedar with earthy and medicinal undertones. Gives me nostalgic vibes of playing in my grandparents wardrobe as a kid. I was not so sure about this tea the first time I had it, but it seems to have grown on me. Definitely, not an everyday drinker or a tea for everyone but I appreciate having it in my stash.

You need:

I've used the grottiest, shittiest knives to cook with, and very nice ones.
Function is basically identical between 90% of knives of any given blade type (chef, cleaver, santoku, etc). An hour on a whetstone turns any knife into a scalpel, and occasional touch ups with a honing rod keep the edge even on soft mystery meat sheet metal knives for months.

Form is the most important aspect. Its was separates them all apart. And, if you pay more, you can get both easily. Good form and whatever you imagine is going to give you noticeably more function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
For one, the "trees" aren't really very tree-like. Secondly, while only a single bunch grows on a single "tree," each will be about 200 bananas total and weigh something like 90lbs or so.
Third, in a small area of about 15ft2, you can grow 4-6 "trees" IE you can grow about a thousand bananas in a space about the size of a small bedroom.
Fourth, bananas are picked and shipped unripe, so the window of usability is quite large. Underripe bananas can be just as useful as ripe ones.
Finally, with proper planning, a grower can produce bananas all year round. While one "tree" can only produce one bunch of 200 bananas every year or so, in tropical areas (or in greenhouses), banana trees can be timed to produce ready-to-pick bananas sectionally IE section 1 will by ready the first week of August and section two the second week and section three the third etc.
Oh, and also, they're perennials. You plant them once and you get bananas every year.
t. grew around banana "trees"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18925914
Competitive eating isn't about being hungry. Actually, being hungry can lessen your chances. The longer you go without food, the more your stomach contracts. The muscles tighten up, and you end up with less room for food. It will relax after you've started eating, as your body realizes what's going on, but by then your brain might already be getting signals of satiation and you'll start to feel full. The key to competitive eating is to cram as much in as possible before your brain catches on. For most people, this is about 20 minutes. The pre-competition exercise for most eaters is to drink a bunch of water to stretch out their stomach and make sure everything is relaxed.

>>18929116
it's not called like this in the netherlands. we just call it a "gietijzeren pan" which translates to "cast iron pan" but dutch technology is used to create them. this is the explanation.

In the seventeenth century, molds for making cast iron objects were developed in the Netherlands using a special sand mixture. The Englishman Abraham Darby became acquainted with this unknown technique in the Netherlands and introduced it to England. After much experimentation, he succeeded in making rock-solid cast iron pans. Because of the Dutch technique, these pans subsequently became known as Dutch Ovens. A name that has always remained.

Flamande
Brasato or any pot roast

Bolognese sauce
Whole or sectioned chicken dishes (not soups though)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I put spray cheese on almost everything I eat. I've can't remember the last time I've eaten in at a fast food place because they don't have spray cheese as a condiment. Even if it makes more sense for my schedule to eat in at a fast food place, I won't unless I remembered to bring a can of spray cheese in my car, and even then, I'll eat it in the car to save myself the embarrassment of having to show the entire restaurant my spray cheese.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

Muga Rioja ES 2018
El Nido Clio 2020
Honoro Vera Garnacha 2020

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As for the Rioja, I kinda just wanted to confirm my suspicion that expensive Tempranillo just isn't worth it. Even at $45 this grape still doesn't make good wine. Sure 2018 is young but it shouldn't need 10 years of age to be drinkable. And this is one of the best Riojas in Spain according to the professionals. So I recommend against buying any expensive tempranillo.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

by volume

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been making a lot of oats recently, I use these 'cracked oats' from Costco which take 5 mins and have a better texture than instant rolled oats.

I boil them in a mixture of water and milk or water and oat milk.
Before I add the oats I add ginger and cinnamon, almond extract, maple syrup, and honey.
Then, some salted butter.
When they're ready to rest I dump in frozen fruit - blueberries, dragon fruit, and acai is a good recent combo. The rapid cooling helps keep them al dente, which makes a better texture for leftovers. I usually make a batch that lasts 3 days or so.

I then top with fresh fruit, granola/nuts, dried berries, and maple syrup. I generally like mine mildly sweet.

For apple oatmeal, I do this but add allspice/clove/nutmeg, add vanilla extract, and replace the honey with sugar and molasses.

I'd like to try a savory version sometime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>long lasting candy
idk wtf you mean
Long lasting as in it takes a while to go off (stale, brittle, sticky etc) or that it takes a while to eat/dissolve?
My mum used to make lemon drops among other candies. Just fresh juice and zest of lemon and a bunch of CANE sugar. That's it. Cooked until it reduces considerably then poured into moulds to cool and harden.
I specify that it must be cane sugar because upon moving to the US, I tried making it with beet sugar and it simply doesn't behave the same way as cane. Once the liquid evaporates off, the sugar turns back into its normal, sand-like consistency IE impossible to make it into candy of any kind.
You can make other sweets in a similar fashion. If you've ever made fresh jam and accidentally overcooked it, you know what I'm talking about: the hardened stuff that sticks behind after pouring your jam out of the pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18926464
katsu is just one example. In the cuisine of many european countries they also have traditions of fried meat cutlets or breaded and fried vegetables that end up served drowned in sauce too. and while your picture is indeed the correct way of serving katsu curry, it's still very common for east Asians to drown the katsu in the curry sauce. asians also like to fry their meat or tofu then drop the whole thing into a soup.

The best way is to have your crispy fried food and not serve it with sauce on it at all, and to instead have the sauce used for quick dipping.

Basically you need wooden/silicone ones for non-stick pans and eggs. The metal ones are for grills and such, and these should be longer to keep your hands out of the fire. Silicone is only really good as a stirrer, it fails as a flipper or smashing tool. So realistically, you can get away with 3: one silicone spatula, a wooden/plastic flipper, one big ass metal one for a grill.

>>18927864
oven you can do naked but brined/basted
whether or not you do plain, brined, or basted, take them out of the package and leave them out for an hour on paper towels, changing once after half an hour. you want them really dry
wings are pretty forgiving when spaced close together since they're small unless they're full wings with drumette/flat/flap still connected. for moist i'd do 400ºF for 20 minutes, for crispier skin i'd do 425-450 for 15 minutes. all ovens are different though and i haven't learned my new one yet, i'm going by my old one
also if you're going to baste with something sweet like teriyaki, only do it for the last 5 or so minutes because it burns quickly. i like charred/burnt flavor but a lot of people don't

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18926455
Sometimes cooking your pasta with the sauce can help, sometimes can destroy what you did. That's because some sauce or condiment don't need to cook too much or don't need to cook, for example pesto don't need to cook, but only to be heated and it's different. Let's take pesto as example OP, pesto don't need to be cooked, after that pasta is ready, drain the pasta, use the same pot you used to cook pasta and put in this pot pasta and pesto and mix with your fork, if it is still hot you don't even need to rekindle the flame.

There are other example where you can thicken (risottare) your pasta, you make your sauce in a pan and you can put pasta (al dente) in the same pan, add water (use the same that you used previusly for pasta) if you don't add water you can't cook your pasta, but do not use too much water or you eliminate the flavour to your sauce, everytime it evaporate add water a little at a time till the pasta is really cooked. Risottare the pasta is usefull release the starch in your plate and give more taste.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I put spray cheese on almost everything I eat. I've can't remember the last time I've eaten in at a fast food place because they don't have spray cheese as a condiment. Even if it makes more sense for my schedule to eat in at a fast food place, I won't unless I remembered to bring a can of spray cheese in my car, and even then, I'll eat it in the car to save myself the embarrassment of having to show the entire restaurant my spray cheese.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

>>18925184
I've been to all sorts of social events connected to work. Management throws nice events for themselves, these are usually worth going to if just for the food, but socialization at these events isn't usually a chore. Conferences and stuff also tend to be reasonable affairs, plus it is nice if travel to a good place is included with it. I got lucky and it was restaurant week when I was on travel for class, shit was cash. Contractor stuff is also pretty nice, usually decent catering and nice meals post meetings. Though I have also been dragged to shit "iconic" places post work shift, but looking back I don't actually mind that, I experienced the local stuff and learned the truth about it.

I've also been to team events and potlucks. These are the "normie" events people complain about. Awkward environment, basic bitch food, and usually with people you are already sick of fucking talking to all the damn time. Last one had shit cardboard pizza, could not wait to GTFO from that one.

I've also been to Army parties. These can range from fun to "mandatory fun". I've got fond memories from these, largely because my time was so fucking shit these events stick out as bright spots of fun. Plus I've worked a few of these as a worker bee running stuff.

Bottom line: company events run the gamut from "this is a blast" to "holy fuck this sucks, let me leave, let me leave". It all depends on the corporate culture and who you are there with.

Also, OP committed a crime against that steak. Probably ruined it and made it into shoe leather.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18928317
That's why I made this thread asking. Because some recipes for example will tell you to coat and rub your meat thoroughly with spices and herbs, then searing the meat until brown. Well by that point many of the seasonings will have been burnt, and even if they aren't burnt they sure as hell will have lost much of their flavor.
So why do so many recipes tell you to do it that way instead of making a sauce with the seasonings to be added to the cooked meat? Doing it this way ensures more control over how much the seasonings get cooked and makes them less likely to burn or lose flavor.

The only reason I can think of why so many chefs instruct you to sear your meat WITH the spices is because chefs can only think in terms of restaurant efficiency - practices in which quality of the meal is sacrificed in favor of getting it done faster, which may be important for professional restaurants serving customers but not for home cooks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: McDonald's fries, nuggets, as well as literally any other fried product in the world including stale potato chips will come out great from an air fryer. Wrap the burgers in a paper towel and microwave them for 45-60 seconds. If they're extremely stale, dampen the paper towel first and then remove the paper towel and let them steam dry when they're hot.

i've salvaged cold mcdonalds, but i also get my cheeseburgers plain or only with onion. i don't like microwaving shit like pickles, ketchup, mustard.
if you must, (I like cold burgers), split the double cheeses in half where there is a bun and a patty on each half, patty face side up, drip a couple drops of water across each patty, and do about 45 seconds, then re-orient them and another 15-30 seconds (even with a rotating microwave)
fries you can just leave in the carton and let them go for a 60-90 seconds, after dripping a bit of water on them. they won't all be good and not for long, but the first quarter/third will be alright.
i inhale nuggets so i've never had any to reheat
